message: The tool should accomplish the following tasks: 1. Open pdf-files 2. Search the file for a predefined set of words 3. highlight the findings, would be cool if highlights were in different colors

Hey, i´m an programming novice. Fiddled around a bit with C on the Arduino platform. At the moment i have a job where i have to search for a set of words in many pdf files. I am looking for a tool for 2 hours now and cannot find one. So i thought, why not dive into python and try to code it myself.
Here's how I'd start:

A direct answer: yes, it's going to be hard when "process" involves reading PDFs, which are not always as logically constructed as one might think. But I can guarantee it would be at least one order of magnitude more difficult in C.

I can see the highlighting feature is not so easy to accomplish, would it possibly make sense to convert the .pdf´s to .txt and write a tool to search and highlight in the raw text? For me, the tool only has to get the job done. I´m just looking for the minimalistic way
is it hard to process pdf-files with python?
thats a nice starting point, thanks
Go to pypi.python.org and search for PDF. You'll find quite a few choices http://pypi.python.org/pypi?%3Aaction=search&term=pdf&submit=search

I picked PDFMiner: http://www.unixuser.org/~euske/python/pdfminer/index.html , which seems to do be capable at least for the opening and searching part. On the bottom of the page you can conveniently find other libraries the author recommends
@jfkreuter you're welcome. On the highlighting part, I'm not so sure it's trivial.
@jfkreuter Do you need to highlight it on the screen only? Or in an output file also?
@jfkreuter regarding the minimalistic way: you can say "less file.pdf" and get the text from file.pdf ... but that's only for unix systems I guess

@0chris sorry, had to study. i would say its not necessary to highlight the words in an output file. It´s ok if i see them on the screen. i have to do the further analysis with excel (yeah, i know)also,  i´ll try "less" on some pdf´s and see how the outcomings are
another straight *nix approach: strings xyz.pdf | grep <pattern>
heyhey..i´m getting near the solution
i´m actually on an *nix system (Mac OS) and found this automator script called pdf to text which outputs the text data of the pdf file

now i can search the .rtf with "strings xyz.rtf | grep <pattern> " and i get the lines where <pattern> is located in. I think I´m understanding regular expressions to get grep to search for multiple words.  Is there any way to
show the context of the words? Like, let´s say the 4 words before and behind of <pattern> ?
and -A to specify the number of lines after the matching line
you also usually have -B to specify number of lines before the matching line
@jfkreuter I would go with egrep... like "strings xyz.rtf | egrep '(word1|word2|word3)'
most grep implementations these days have a -C option to specify how many lines of context you want surrounding the line that contains the matching string
not sure how you'd go about just getting X matching words on either side of your needle without some actual programming.... though I am curious if it's possible with regular command line tools!
There are many pdftotxt tools but I would suggest you use pdfminer to turn it into HTML then use lxml.html to do the search and diffs.
